title: The Life of Henry the Eighth
full_title: All Is True, or The Famous History of the Life of King Henry VIII

themes.theme_explanation: Henry VIII’s quest for control over his marriage and kingdom drives political maneuvers, while Wolsey’s ambition leads to his downfall.
The conflict between Henry’s desire for divorce and Catholic doctrine sparks religious reform, shaping England’s break with Rome.
Henry’s divorce from Katherine and marriage to Anne Boleyn highlight the personal and political stakes of royal unions.
Court intrigues, such as Wolsey’s schemes and Norfolk’s opposition, reveal the treacherous dynamics of political power.
The birth of Elizabeth secures Henry’s dynasty, emphasizing the critical role of succession in stabilizing the monarchy.
The play questions justice through Buckingham’s execution and Katherine’s trial, exposing the influence of power on legal outcomes.

famous_quotes.quote: Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot that it do singe yourself
famous_quotes.speaker: Norfolk
famous_quotes.explanation: Norfolk warns against excessive vengeance, advising caution to avoid self-destruction.

famous_quotes.quote: I have touched the highest point of all my greatness
famous_quotes.speaker: Cardinal Wolsey
famous_quotes.explanation: Wolsey reflects on his fall from power, acknowledging the fleeting nature of ambition.

famous_quotes.quote: Men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues we write in water
famous_quotes.speaker: Griffith
famous_quotes.explanation: Griffith notes that flaws are remembered enduringly, while virtues fade, commenting on human legacy.

famous_quotes.quote: Farewell, a long farewell, to all my greatness!
famous_quotes.speaker: Cardinal Wolsey
famous_quotes.explanation: Wolsey laments his downfall, accepting the end of his political dominance with resignation.

famous_quotes.quote: This is the state of man: today he puts forth the tender leaves of hopes
famous_quotes.speaker: Cardinal Wolsey
famous_quotes.explanation: Wolsey compares life to a plant, fragile and subject to sudden ruin, reflecting on his own fall.

summary: King Henry VIII navigates political and personal turmoil, divorcing Katherine of Aragon to marry Anne Boleyn, causing religious and diplomatic strife. Cardinal Wolsey's ambition leads to his downfall, while the birth of Elizabeth heralds hope for England's future.
